sub_topic: Calculating the effect of changing the concentration of reactants or products on the equilibrium position of a redox reaction
message_1:
What is the new equilibrium constant for the following redox reaction when the concentration of reactant iodine is doubled, assuming all other concentrations remain constant:

2I^- + Cl2 ⇌ 2Cl^- + I2    Kc = 10.0 at 25°C
message_2:
When the concentration of a reactant is changed, the equilibrium constant (Kc) remains the same, as it is only affected by temperature changes. However, the reaction will shift to re-establish equilibrium.

In this case, when the concentration of iodine (I2) is doubled, the reaction will shift towards the reactants to counteract the change and re-establish equilibrium. The new equilibrium concentrations of the species will be different, but the equilibrium constant (Kc) will still be 10.0 at 25°C.
